statement.tex: %text If $x=a\sin t$ and $y=a\cdot \left( \cos t + \log\frac{t}{2}\right)$, then find $\dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2}$ %

\\ %text \bf{First, a theoretical question}
If $x=t^2$ and $y=t^3$, then is the following true? %

\\ %text Given that $x=a\sin t$ and $y=a\cdot\left(\cos t + \log\tan\frac{t}{2} \right)$, which of the following shows correct values for $\frac{dx}{dt},\frac{dy}{dt}$ and therefore $\frac{dy}{dx}$? %

\\ %text \bf{Right or wrong?}
Given that $\dfrac{dy}{dx} = \cot t, \dfrac{d^2 y}{dx^2}$ will evaluate to the following. %

options.tex: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \dfrac{dx}{dt} & a\cdot\cos t \\ \hline \dfrac{dy}{dt} & a\cdot\left[ -\sin t + \dfrac{1}{\sin t}\right] = a\cdot\dfrac{\cos^2 t}{\sin t}\\ \hline \dfrac{dy}{dx} & \cot t \hline \end{tabular}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \dfrac{dx}{dt} & a\cdot\cos t \\ \hline \dfrac{dy}{dt} & a\cdot\dfrac{\cos t}{\sin t}\\ \hline \dfrac{dy}{dx} & \dfrac{1}{\sin t} = \csc t \hline \end{tabular}

reason.tex: \begin{align} x &= a\sin t \implies \dfrac{dx}{dt} = a\cos t \\ y &= a\cdot\left( \cos t + \log\tan\frac{t}{2} \right) \\ \implies\frac{dy}{dt} &= a\cdot\left[ -\sin t + \underbrace{\dfrac{1}{\tan\frac{t}{2}} \cdot\sec^2\frac{t}{2}\cdot\frac{1}{2}}_{\text{Chain Rule}}\right] \\ &= a\cdot\left[ -\sin t + \frac{1}{2\cdot \frac{\sin\frac{t}{2}}{\cos\frac{t}{2}}\cdot\cos^2\frac{t}{2}}\right] \\ &= a\cdot \left[-\sin t + \frac{1}{\underbrace{2\cdot\sin\frac{t}{2}\cdot\cos\frac{t}{2}}_{=\sin 2\cdot\frac{t}{2} = \sin t}} \right] \\ &= a\cdot\left[ -\sin t + \frac{1}{\sin t}\right] = a\cdot\frac{1-\sin^2 t }{\sin t} \\ &= a\cdot\frac{\cos^2 t}{\sin t} \\ \implies \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \dfrac{\frac{dy}{dt}}{\frac{dx}{dt}} = \dfrac{a\cdot\frac{\cos^2 t}{\sin t}}{a\cdot\cos t} = \cot t \end{align}
